name: 王雅璇
objective: This course aims to guide students in understanding the role of archives in the preservation, exhibition, and value-added application of cultural materials. Starting with the fundamental concepts of archives, the course explores how curatorial methods and innovative value-adding strategies can transform historical texts into cultural content with contemporary relevance and market potential. Through the integration of domestic and international case studies, topics will cover institutional archives, community memory, digital translation, and brand licensing. Students will engage in group discussions, project-based assignments, and site visits to learn how to navigate the entire process—from data analysis and curatorial concept development to creative value-added production—while cultivating interdisciplinary practical skills and creative thinking.
schedule:
week 1 9/10 Course Introduction: What is an archive? Overview of value-added applications
week 2  9/17 Fundamentals of Archival Texts: Key concepts and classifications
week 3 9/24 How Do Archives Become Cultural Resources? Cultural roles and value of archives
week 4 10/1 Introduction to Online Cultural Platforms and Databases
week 5 10/8  Curation Basics I: Archival narratives (in-class exercise)
week 6 10/15 Curation Basics II: Archival display strategies
week 7 10/22 Case Study Presentations I: Archival curation case reports (Group presentations)
week 8 10/29 Case Study Discussions II: Comparative insights on curatorial practices
week 9 11/5  Midterm Assessment: Submission of midterm report
week 10 11/12 Field Trip: On-site visit to an archival or curatorial institution (The actual visit date will be adjusted based on the availability of the host organization)
week 11 11/19 Curatorial Design Practice I: Archive selection and contextual analysis
week 12 1/26 Curatorial Design Practice II: Narrative building and exhibition planning 
week 13 12/3 Group Presentations: project proposal showcase
week 14 12/10 Value-Added Perspectives I: Translation and interpretation of archival content (in-class exercise)
week 15 12/17 Value-Added Perspectives II: Visual translation and productization case studies
week 16 12/24 Value-Added Strategy Practice: Extended applications and product proposal development
week 17 12/31 Final Group Presentations: Value-added product or campaign proposals
week 18 1/7 Final Submission: Turn in final written report
